Package nl.uu.cs.aplib.mainConcepts

Class Goal

java.lang.Object
nl.uu.cs.aplib.mainConcepts.Goal
Direct Known Subclasses:
TestGoal
public class Goal extends Object
An instance of this class represents a goal that can be given to an agent (an instance of SimpleAgent or its subclasses). To be more precise, an agent expects a GoalStructure, and a Goal is the simplest/primitive form a GoalStructure. Note that when a Goal is given to an agent, the agent will expect the the goal to be accompanied with a Tactic which the agent will then use to solve the goal. Use the method withTactic to attach a Tactic to a Goal.

A Goal is essentially a predicate over some domain. You can imagine it as a domain of 'proposals' to be proposed to the goal. Proposals on which the predicate returns true are 'solutions' of the goal. When a goal is given to an agent, the task of the agent is to find a solution for the goal.

A goal can specify its estimated minimum computation time budget. The agent solving the goal will try (but not committed to) to allocate at least this amount of total computation time for working on the goal. The computation time of an agent with respect to a goal is defined as the total time the agent spends per invocation of its update() method while solving the goal. The time that elapses between two invocations of update() is not counted. If no time budget is specified, then the budget is assumed as infinite.

Optionally, we can attach a distance function to a goal. A distance function is a function from the goal domain of proposals to Double. It is a measure of how 'far' a given proposal is from being a solution. This information might be exploitable by a strategy when it searches for a solution, e.g. if the strategy implements a search algorithm (hill climbing, evolutionary, etc).

Author:
wish

    • desc

      public String desc

  • Constructor Details

    • Goal

      public Goal​(String name)
      Create a blank instance of a Goal. It will have no actual predicate as the actual goal.
      Parameters:
      name - A name to be associated with the goal.

  • Method Details

    • withEpsilon

      public Goal withEpsilon​(Double e)
      Set the value of eplison. The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • toSolve_

      public Goal toSolve_​(Predicate predicateToSolve)
      Set the predicate which would serve as the predicate to solve. The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • ftoSolve_

      public Goal ftoSolve_​(Function<Object,​Double> goalfunction)
      Set the given function as a goal function. A proposal o is a solution if abs(goalfunction(o)) is a value less than epsilon (default is 0.005).
      Parameters:
      goalfunction - the goal function to solve.
      Returns:
      The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • toSolve

      public <Proposal> Goal toSolve​(Predicate<Proposal> predicateToSolve)
      Set the predicate which would serve as the predicate to solve. The more general typing of the method's signature is for convenience, to allow you to explicitly specify the type of the goal's proposals domain at the point where this method is called, e.g. as in: 
       Goal g = new Goal().toSolve((Integer x) -> x == 9999);
      The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • ftoSolve

      public <Proposal> Goal ftoSolve​(Function<Proposal,​Double> predicateToSolve)
      Set the given function as a goal function. A proposal o is a solution if abs(goalfunction(o)) is a value less than epsilon (default is 0.005). The more general typing of the method's signature is for convenience, to allow you to explicitly specify the type of the goal's proposals domain at the point where this method is called, e.g. as in: 
       Goal g = new Goal().ftoSolve((Integer x) -> x - 9999);
      The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • withTactic

      public Goal withTactic​(Tactic S)
      Set the strategy to that a solving agent can use to solve this goal. The method returns this Goal itself so that it can be used in the Fluent Interface style.

    • getTactic

      public Tactic getTactic()

    • propose

      public final void propose​(Object proposal)
      Check if a given proposal satisfied this goal (so, if the proposal is a solution). If the proposal is indeed a solution the status of this goal will be set to SUCCESS.

      A null proposal is always rejected.

    • getName

      public String getName()

    • getProposal

      public Object getProposal()
      Return the last non-null proposal that was tested by this goal (see the method propose_(Object)).

    • getSolution

      public Object getSolution()
      Return the last proposal that was tested by this goal (see the method propose_(Object)) that turned out to be a solution. If there was none, null is returned.

    • lift

      public GoalStructure.PrimitiveGoal lift()
      To lift this goal to become an instance of Solution. Conceptually, a Goal is a simplest type of Solution. Technically, to be more precise, Goal is not a subclass of Solution. The corresponding representation of Goal as a Solution is called GoalStructure.PrimitiveGoal, which is a subclass of Solution. So, this method will lift this goal to a GoalStructure.PrimitiveGoal.
      Returns:
      A new instance of GoalStructure.PrimitiveGoal that wrap around this goal.

    • getStatus

      public ProgressStatus getStatus()
      Return the progress status of this goal (INPROGRESS, SUCCESS, or FAILED).

    • distance

      public Double distance()
      If a distance function has been specified for this goal, this will return the absolute distance between the last proposed and non-null proposal to being a solution.
